page.lettertext:
fol.331r
1592 29 Septem
b
To my L. Trea
s
May it please your good L.
S
r
Francis Vere
having bin in
Zeland
a good while sins to see the c
o
panies embarked, I doe
not doubt but your L. is advertised fr
o
him of all
t
hath bin
re
q
sit. There c
a
be no stay
t
I c
a
imagine but onely in
e
winde w
c
hath bin of late very variable heere,
t
I c
a
not well
c
o
jecture how it hath bin in Zeland. It is signified unto
me
t
e
States
of
t
Province have stormed exceedingly,
t
I
should write to make a stay of
e paym
t
of
Bergh
e
till they had
s
e
t some other c
o
panies in lieu of
e Englishe w
c
her
M
tie
re
q
red. But notwithstanding their offense,
t
effect hath
e
sued
w
c
I did expect, wherby her M
tie
hath bin served. For they
ordened out of hand, to send a supplie of their owne repar-
titi
o
: for w
c
I am
suaded
t
unles I had
ceeded in such
emptorie sort, they would ether have tak
e
no order at all
or trained me too long w
t
some frivolous delay: up
o
supposal
haps,
t
rather th
e
e
Governour
would leave
e towne
op
e
to
e Enemies invasi
o
, as he must of necessitie, if he
left
e garris
o
unfournished, he would not be
suaded to part
w
t
e c
o
panies. And yet if he should,
ei knewe they had
e
meanes, to succour it on
e soddaine. I have very
much a doe in every meeting in this place, to answear their
c
o
plaintes, for this drawing fr
o
hens of her M
ts
aide.
But as I signify unto th
e
, so I know it is certaine, and
fewe of th
e
doe much deny it, The State
s
of these Prov
i
ces
through her M
ts
assistance is brought to great security,
such as no m
a
could expect to be effected so soone, nor,
e power of
e Enemy being throughly considered, they
themselves c
a
not wish to stand in better termes. And
in
t
respect, if
ey would waigh, as they ought, how much
it did c
o
cerne as well themselves as her M
tie
to chase
e
Enemy out
of
of
Britaine,
they would be more forward
in dimissing
e c
o
panies. In their late c
o
sult
a
on
about
e further imploym
t
of their forces abroade, whereof
I made m
e
ti
o
in my last to your L. they have fully
resolved to passe
e Rhine: w
c
is intended about Embrick
fol.331v
a towne upon
e Rhine, and in
e co
u
trey of
Cleve,
very
neere unto
Sgravenwert
or
e Talhuis, w
c
is
e place,
where
e Rhine doth devide it self in two. They
doe acco
u
t by
t
meanes to stoppe
e Enemy of his passage
or to force him to dis
se
e greatest part of his troupes.
Howbeit there is a bruite at this p
nt
,
t
for
e assurance
of his passage, he hath tak
e
Duisberch,
w
c
is situat on
e
Rhine, and is upward fr
o
Wesel
about 4 dutche miles.
It is also halfe c
o
cluded,
t
if the
D. of Parma
c
o
tinue at
e Spa, or in
e quarters thereabout, all
e horsm
e
of
e army shall make a soddaine cavalcado, to assault
him in his lodging. By either of these attempts,
if
e issue be as happy as
e Project is cast, it is thought
e
Frenche K.
may be greatly relieved.
Mons
r
Buzenval
hath solicited very hard to obtene a good
a
swear
to
e suite of
e King, for
e loane of certaine mony, as I
writte
u
to your L.
e 19 of Au
g
. But there is nothing yet
done, nor they doe not deale about it: wherby his hope,
as it seemeth, is very slender. I am
certified at this instant, by a l
re
brought unto me, fr
o
e Gouvernour of Bergh
e
,
t
e States of Zeland have s
e
t
him but 4 Dutche c
o
panies, to supply
e roomes of 6 English
t
are re
q
red by her Hig
nes
. Whether they doe it, to force him
by
t
meanes, to send but 4 in all, reserving 2 of
e 6, or
for
t
they thinke it suffici
e
t, to keepe
e towne fr
o
e Enemy,
though there should be but foure in place of
e six, I c
a
not yet understand. But
e Gouvernor deteneth two
Englishe c
o
panies, of
e n
o
ber of those
t
should be sent
And w
t
all, because they send him no supply of Canoniers, [he]
will
mitte but half
of
18 w
c
are demanded by her M
tie
[to]
depart w
t
e c
o
panies:
p
tending
t
e towne c
a
not oth[erwise]
be defended. But I will write directly to him, to se[nd]
of hand both all
e 6 copanies and all
e canoniers. [But]
otherwise
e officer of
e T
re
r shall be willed w
t
hold [their]
weekely intertenm
t
, untill it be
fourmed. For as [I will]
fol.332r
signify, if it be so,
at
e towne may be held, while
e Enemy,
at this p
nt
, is busied abroad, w
t
e helpe of those 4 (w
c
Martial m
e
must judge) both her M
tie
and
e co
u
trey will
cast
e blame up
o
him, for being over
p
cise: w
c
he hath to
consider in w
t
maner he will answear. But if it fall
out in discourse,
t
this supply of
e States is too weake in
very deede for defense of
e place, there is no doubt but by
refraining fr
o
paying of
e souldiours detened, he shall
have p
nt
ly s
e
t unto him some further renforcem
t
. Wherup
o
I have writt
e
to
e officer of
e T
re
r to
sist c
o
tinually in
w
t
holding
e imprest of
e c
o
panies behind, but w
t
e advise
and good liking of
S
r
Francis Vere
, who being made acquainted
w
t
all my
ceeding and p
nt
there in place, will acc
o
plishe,
I am certaine, w
t
soever shall be needfull, if he may be
obeyed.
And thus I take my humble leave. At
e Hage
Sep
t
29 1592.
